title: Dollar-Cost Averaging (DCA)
concept: Dollar-Cost Averaging (DCA) is an investment strategy where an investor allocates a fixed amount of money into an asset at regular intervals, regardless of its price. The purpose is to reduce the impact of market volatility and avoid mistiming the market. By buying consistently, the investor accumulates more shares when prices are low and fewer when prices are high.
calculation: Investment Amount ÷ Current Price = Number of Units Purchased. Example: An investor invests $500 per month into Bitcoin. If BTC = $25,000 in January, they buy 0.02 BTC. If BTC = $20,000 in February, they buy 0.025 BTC. Over time, the average purchase cost smooths out.
parameters: Key parameters include fixed investment amount, frequency (weekly, monthly), and asset selection (stock, ETF, crypto, etc.).
use_cases: Long-term wealth building without worrying about timing the market.
Investing in volatile assets like crypto or emerging markets.
Disciplined savings strategy for retirement accounts.
advantages: Minimizes risk of buying at market peaks.
disadvantages: May underperform lump-sum investing in strong bull markets.
Requires discipline and patience.
Does not protect against long-term declines.
example: Investors who DCA’d into the S&P 500 during the 2008 financial crisis benefited from consistently lower prices and strong long-term returns when the market recovered.
variations: Value Averaging - adjusting investment amount based on portfolio performance.
Reverse DCA - gradually selling portions of assets over time instead of buying.

title: Value Investing
concept: Value Investing, popularized by Benjamin Graham and Warren Buffett, focuses on buying undervalued securities trading below their intrinsic value. The idea is that markets occasionally misprice stocks, and patient investors can profit when prices eventually reflect true value.
calculation: Intrinsic Value = (Future Cash Flows) ÷ (Discount Rate). Example: If a company’s intrinsic value is estimated at $100 per share but trades at $70, a value investor sees a buying opportunity.
parameters: Metrics include Price-to-Earnings (P/E), Price-to-Book (P/B), Free Cash Flow, and Margin of Safety.
use_cases: Contrarian plays in sectors hit by temporary issues.
Building long-term portfolios with stable businesses.
advantages: Focus on fundamentals and real business value.
Potential for strong returns if markets correct mispricing.
disadvantages: Stocks can remain undervalued for years.
Requires detailed fundamental analysis.
May underperform during growth-driven bull markets.
example: Warren Buffett’s investment in Coca-Cola during the late 1980s, when the stock was undervalued relative to its brand strength and earnings power, is a classic example of value investing.
variations: Deep Value Investing - buying extremely undervalued distressed companies.
Relative Value Investing - comparing valuation multiples across peers.

title: Growth Investing
concept: Growth Investing focuses on companies with above-average earnings, revenue, or market expansion potential. Investors prioritize future potential over current valuation, often investing in innovative sectors such as technology, biotech, or renewable energy.
calculation: Key metrics include EPS growth rate, Revenue CAGR, and PEG ratio (Price/Earnings-to-Growth). Example: A stock with P/E = 30 may still be attractive if its EPS is growing 25% annually.
parameters: Focus on revenue growth, market size, product innovation, and competitive advantage.
use_cases: Investing in emerging technologies (AI, EVs, biotech).
Capturing secular growth trends like cloud computing.
advantages: High potential returns during bull markets.
Exposure to innovative companies with exponential growth potential.
disadvantages: Often overvalued with high P/E multiples.
Vulnerable to market corrections and rising interest rates.
High volatility compared to stable dividend stocks.
example: Amazon in the early 2000s was considered overvalued by value investors, but growth investors who focused on revenue expansion saw massive long-term returns.

title: Index Investing
concept: Index Investing is a passive strategy where investors buy index funds or ETFs that replicate major market indices (e.g., S&P 500, NASDAQ). The goal is to match market performance instead of beating it, leveraging diversification and low fees.
calculation: Return = Weighted average return of all index components. Example: Investing $10,000 into an S&P 500 ETF mirrors the performance of the 500 companies in the index.
parameters: Choice of index, fund expense ratio, and tracking error.
advantages: Low cost compared to active management.
Historically outperforms most active managers over time.
disadvantages: No chance to outperform the market.
Exposed to overall market downturns.
Limited flexibility (cannot avoid weak sectors).
example: Jack Bogle’s Vanguard S&P 500 Index Fund, launched in 1976, revolutionized investing by giving retail investors low-cost access to broad markets.

title: Contrarian Investing
concept: Contrarian Investing involves going against prevailing market sentiment. Contrarians buy assets that are out of favor and sell those that are popular, betting that mass psychology often misprices securities.
calculation: No fixed formula - relies on market sentiment indicators (VIX, put/call ratio) and valuation metrics. Example: Buying oil stocks when oil prices crash and sentiment is extremely bearish.
parameters: Indicators include sentiment surveys, short interest ratios, and valuation spreads.
use_cases: Timing market reversals based on psychology.
advantages: Often identifies opportunities missed by the herd.
Can yield outsized returns in extreme conditions.
disadvantages: Requires patience - mispricing can persist for years.
High psychological pressure (going against consensus).
Risk of catching falling knives in declining sectors.
example: During the 2008 crisis, contrarian investors who bought bank stocks at extreme lows reaped massive gains in the following recovery.
variations: Deep Contrarian - targeting extremely distressed assets.
Relative Contrarian - opposing consensus within specific sectors.

title: Momentum Investing
concept: Momentum Investing is based on the principle that assets that have performed well recently will continue to perform well in the short-to-medium term, and vice versa for underperforming assets. The strategy capitalizes on herd behavior and trend persistence.
calculation: Momentum Score = % Change in Price over past 3-12 months. Example: A stock up 40% over the last year may be ranked higher than one up 10%.
parameters: Lookback periods (3, 6, 12 months), rebalancing frequency, and universe of stocks considered.
use_cases: Short-term trading based on relative strength.
advantages: Backed by strong academic evidence (momentum anomaly).
Can outperform value and growth in certain cycles.
disadvantages: High turnover and transaction costs.
Vulnerable to sudden trend reversals.
Requires strict risk management.
example: Momentum funds that bought tech stocks in 2020 significantly outperformed broader markets as trends persisted.
variations: Absolute Momentum - buy only if return > 0.

title: Dividend Investing
concept: Dividend Investing focuses on stocks that pay regular dividends, providing investors with steady income alongside capital appreciation. Popular among retirees, this style emphasizes stability and cash flow.
calculation: Dividend Yield = Annual Dividend per Share ÷ Share Price. Example: A $2 annual dividend on a $40 stock = 5% yield.
parameters: Dividend yield, payout ratio, dividend growth rate, and company stability.
use_cases: Long-term wealth building through dividend reinvestment.
advantages: Reliable cash flow regardless of market swings.
disadvantages: High yields may indicate financial distress.
Limited exposure to high-growth sectors.
Dividend cuts can damage income streams.
example: Investors in Johnson & Johnson have benefited from decades of consistent dividend increases, making it a classic dividend stock.

title: ESG / Sustainable Investing
concept: ESG (Environmental, Social, Governance) investing integrates sustainability factors into investment decisions. Investors prioritize companies with strong ethical practices, environmental responsibility, and social governance, aiming for long-term performance aligned with values.
calculation: ESG Score = Weighted average of environmental, social, and governance metrics (varies by provider). Example: A fund may exclude fossil fuel companies while favoring renewable energy leaders.
parameters: Criteria include carbon footprint, labor practices, board diversity, and compliance history.
use_cases: Reducing long-term risk from climate change.
Attracting institutional capital with ESG mandates.
disadvantages: ESG ratings vary widely by provider.
May underperform in non-ESG-friendly sectors.
Risk of greenwashing by companies.
example: The surge in ESG-focused ETFs in the 2020s reflects investor demand for sustainable portfolios.
variations: Positive Screening - selecting leaders in ESG performance.

title: Sector Rotation
concept: Sector Rotation involves shifting investments between economic sectors based on the business cycle. The strategy assumes that different sectors outperform during different phases such as expansion, peak, recession, and recovery.
calculation: Rotation decisions often rely on macroeconomic indicators like GDP growth, interest rates, and inflation. Example: In early recovery, investors rotate into consumer discretionary and industrials.
parameters: Economic indicators, market cycle analysis, and relative sector performance.
use_cases: Active portfolio management aligned with economic cycles.
Tactical asset allocation for ETFs and mutual funds.
advantages: Enhances returns compared to static allocation.
disadvantages: Requires accurate timing of cycles.
High transaction costs if over-rotated.
Difficult to predict sector leaders consistently.
example: During the 2020 pandemic recovery, investors rotated heavily into tech and healthcare sectors, which outperformed other areas.

title: Buy and Hold
concept: Buy and Hold is a long-term strategy where investors purchase securities and hold them for years or decades, regardless of market volatility. The philosophy is that markets rise over time, and patience leads to compounded returns.
calculation: Return = (Ending Value - Initial Investment) ÷ Initial Investment × 100%. Example: $10,000 invested in the S&P 500 in 1980, held until 2020, grew exponentially despite multiple recessions.
parameters: Asset choice, holding period, reinvestment policy.
use_cases: Retirement accounts and long-term wealth building.
Investors who want minimal trading activity.
advantages: Low costs due to minimal trading.
disadvantages: Exposure to major downturns without protection.
May miss opportunities from active rebalancing.
Requires patience and long-term perspective.
example: Investors who held the S&P 500 through the dot-com crash and 2008 crisis still enjoyed significant gains by 2020.

title: Income Investing
concept: Income Investing focuses on generating steady cash flow from assets such as bonds, REITs, preferred stocks, and dividend-paying companies. The goal is to create reliable income streams rather than capital appreciation.
calculation: Yield = Annual Income ÷ Investment Value. Example: A $1,000 bond paying $50 annually = 5% yield.
parameters: Focus on yield, payout stability, credit risk, and maturity dates.
use_cases: Diversification with fixed income and real estate.
disadvantages: Lower long-term returns than growth stocks.
Interest rate risk affects bond prices.
Inflation erodes purchasing power of fixed income.
example: REITs became popular income investments in the 2000s, offering high yields from real estate portfolios.

title: Event-Driven Hedge Fund Strategy
concept: Event-Driven investing focuses on exploiting mispricings caused by corporate events such as mergers, acquisitions, bankruptcies, or restructurings. Hedge funds use this strategy to generate alpha from market inefficiencies.
calculation: Example: In a merger arbitrage, if Company A offers to buy Company B for $50, but B trades at $48, investors buy B shares, betting the spread closes when the deal finalizes.
parameters: Corporate event calendars, deal spreads, regulatory approvals.
advantages: Less dependent on overall market direction.
disadvantages: Complex and requires deep research.
Event risks such as deals collapsing.
Limited opportunities compared to broad market investing.
example: Merger arbitrage funds profited heavily during the AOL–Time Warner deal in 2000.

title: Global Macro Hedge Fund Strategy
concept: Global Macro investing is a hedge fund strategy that seeks to profit from macroeconomic trends and geopolitical events by trading across asset classes such as equities, bonds, currencies, and commodities.
calculation: Positions are based on macro forecasts - for example, betting on interest rate hikes by shorting bonds. Example: A fund might short the yen while buying U.S. Treasuries in anticipation of policy divergence.
parameters: Global economic indicators, central bank policy, geopolitical analysis.
use_cases: Commodities trades tied to geopolitical events.
advantages: Potential for massive gains in macro shifts.
disadvantages: High risk and volatility.
Requires deep macroeconomic expertise.
Can underperform during stable markets.
example: George Soros's famous bet against the British pound in 1992 (Black Wednesday) is a classic global macro trade.
variations: Discretionary Macro - human decision making based on analysis.
Systematic Macro - algorithmic strategies driven by quantitative models.

title: Factor Investing
concept: Factor Investing involves targeting specific drivers of returns (factors) such as value, size, momentum, quality, and volatility. Instead of buying broad indices, investors tilt portfolios toward factors that historically provide risk-adjusted outperformance.
calculation: Performance Attribution = Exposure * Factor Return. Example: A portfolio overweight in 'value' stocks gains if the value factor outperforms the market.
parameters: Common factors: Value (low P/E), Size (small-cap premium), Momentum (past winners), Quality (high ROE), Low Volatility.
use_cases: Smart beta ETFs tilted toward factors.
disadvantages: Factors can underperform for long stretches.
Data mining risk if factors are poorly defined.
Requires monitoring and rebalancing.
example: MSCI Factor Indices and iShares Smart Beta ETFs allow investors to capture factor premiums systematically.

title: Quantitative Investing
concept: Quantitative Investing uses mathematical models, algorithms, and statistical analysis to identify opportunities. Decisions are data-driven rather than based on human judgment, often involving big data, machine learning, and backtesting.
calculation: Strategies can include statistical arbitrage, factor modeling, or AI-driven signals. Example: A quant model may screen thousands of stocks for specific anomalies and automatically rebalance.
parameters: Inputs include price data, fundamental metrics, sentiment data, and macroeconomic indicators.
use_cases: Algorithmic trading in equities and futures.
advantages: Scalable to large datasets and markets.
Can identify hidden patterns not visible to humans.
disadvantages: Requires advanced technical infrastructure.
Model risk from overfitting or bad assumptions.
Performance depends on data quality.
example: Renaissance Technologies' Medallion Fund is one of the most successful quantitative hedge funds, leveraging advanced algorithms for decades.

title: Swing / Position Investing
concept: Swing or Position Investing bridges short-term trading and long-term investing. Investors hold positions for days to weeks (swing) or weeks to months (position), aiming to profit from medium-term market moves.
calculation: Return = (Sell Price - Buy Price) ÷ Buy Price. Example: Buying a stock at $50 and selling two weeks later at $60 yields a 20% gain.
parameters: Time horizon (days to months), entry/exit signals (technical and fundamental), and risk management (stop-loss, position sizing).
use_cases: Trading around earnings reports or catalysts.
Balancing between active trading and long-term holding.
advantages: Can capture significant price moves without constant monitoring.
Flexibility across technical and fundamental signals.
disadvantages: Still requires timing and discipline.
Higher risk than buy-and-hold investing.
Exposed to overnight/weekend gaps.
example: A swing investor might buy Apple stock ahead of a new iPhone launch and sell after the product announcement rally.
